    Spheres in Bricklayer

    Topics on this page

    • Sphere functions in Bricklayer Level 4
      • Bricklayer sphere function
      • List of colors?
      • Bricklayer hollowSphere function

    In this post we’ll explore spheres in Bricklayer Level 4. For an introduction to programming in the Level 4, check out this post.

    Where you see this icon,

    click on it to download the associated bricklayer program.

    Sphere functions in Bricklayer Level 4

    Bricklayer has two sphere functions: sphere and hollowSphere. Official documentation on these and other Level-4 functions is available at bricklayer.org (Apps -> Bricklayer -> Level 4 - Document). In this post, we’ll start with the sphere function.

    Bricklayer sphere function

    The sphere function produces a sphere (duh!), i.e., a ball. This is a 3D artifact. To create a sphere, we need to know three things:

    • how big it should be
    • what color(s) it should be
    • where it should be

    These three things define the parameters for the sphere function. Specifically, the parameters are:

    • radius
    • a list of colors, written as [color1,color2,etc]
    • the center, written as a location in 3D space

    The sphere command looks like:

    sphere radius [color1,color2,etc] (x,y,z)

    The following command creates a blue sphere with radius 10 with center (15,15,15): 

    sphere 10 [BLUE] (15,15,15);

    Let’s put three side-by-side (radii 5, 10, and 15) for perspective. 

    sphere 5  [BLUE] (10,20,20);
sphere 10 [BLUE] (30,20,20);
sphere 15 [BLUE] (60,20,20);

    List of colors?

    Let’s explore what happens when we have more than one color in our list of colors. I’ll change up our three spheres as follows. 

    sphere 5  [BLUE,YELLOW] (10,20,20);
sphere 10 [RED, GREEN] (30,20,20);
sphere 15 [PINK, VIOLET] (60,20,20);

    But we’re not limited to just two colors. You can include as many as you’d like. Here’s one with three colors. 

    sphere 10 [RED,ORANGE,YELLOW] (15,15,15);

    At this point if you’ve been running the .bl files yourself, you may have noticed that as your artifacts include more bricks, it can take longer for your computer to display them. It is easy to generate a lot of bricks when creating spheres. In fact, we can look at the output in the bricklayer console window to see how many bricks are in an artifact. The screenshot below shows how to look for this (first scroll to the bottom of the console window, then up until you see this part). Notice that our red, orange, and yellow sphere is made up of 4,945 bricks!

    Bricklayer hollowSphere function

    The hollowSphere function provides a way to create the same look as the sphere command without all the inner bricks that one cannot see. The parameters are the same except for one additional parameter for hollowSphere to indicate the thickness of the surface of the sphere. The maximum value for this is 10 and it yields a sphere that looks exactly like the output from the sphere command, but with the unseen bricks deleted. This allows us to create larger spheres without slowing down the computer too much.

    The general form of the hollowSphere command is:

    hollowSphere radius thickness [colors] location;

    I’ll create a sphere that looks like the previous one using hollowSphere with a thickness of 10. 

    hollowSphere 10 10 [RED,ORANGE,YELLOW] (15,15,15);

    Now let’s check the bricklayer console to see how many bricks are in this one.

    2392 bricks in the hollow sphere vs. 4945 in the solid sphere. Using hollowSphere allows us to create larger spheres with no change in appearance from the outside of the sphere.

    What if we used a smaller value for the thickness? Let’s try 5! 

    hollowSphere 10 5 [RED,ORANGE,YELLOW] (15,15,15);

    The outside of the sphere is not solid now. Let’s try thickness = 1. 

    hollowSphere 10 1 [RED,ORANGE,YELLOW] (15,15,15);

    As the thickness decreases, the number of visible bricks on the outside of the sphere also decreases.

    Mar 1, 2019 by Betty Love
